Rotation beyond the fourth quadrant \((360^\circ<\theta)\)

If the vector \(OP\) continues to rotate around the circle of unit radius then in the next complete rotation \(\theta\) increases from \(360^\circ\) to \(720^\circ\). However, a \(\theta\) value of, say, \(405^\circ\) is indistinguishable from one of \(45^\circ\) (just one extra complete revolution is involved).

So \(\sin(405^\circ)=\sin(45^\circ)=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \text{ and } \cos(405^\circ)=\cos(45^\circ)=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

In general \(\sin(360^\circ+x^\circ)=\sin(x^\circ), \cos(360^\circ+x^\circ)=\cos(x^\circ)\)

Key Point

If \(n\) is any integer, then

\[\begin{aligned} \sin (x^\circ+360 n^\circ) &\equiv \sin(x^\circ) \\ \cos (x^\circ+360 n^\circ) &\equiv \cos(x^\circ) \end{aligned}\]

or, since \(360^\circ\equiv2\pi \text{ radians}\), \[\begin{aligned} \sin (x + 2\pi n) &\equiv \sin(x) \\ \cos (x + 2\pi n) &\equiv \cos(x) \end{aligned}\]

We say that the functions \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\) are periodic with period (in radian measure) of \(2\pi\).
